description:
Lupinus angustifolius, commonly known as the narrow-leaved lupin or blue lupin, is a species of lupin native to the Mediterranean region, including countries such as Spain, Italy, and Greece. It is a herbaceous annual plant that typically grows to a height of 30-80 cm.

The leaves of Lupinus angustifolius are narrow and linear, giving the plant its distinctive appearance. The flowers are typically blue or purple in color and are arranged in terminal, spike-like inflorescences. The fruits of the plant are legumes, containing several seeds.

Lupinus angustifolius is a member of the Fabaceae family, also known as the legume or pea family. It is known for its ability to fix atmospheric nitrogen through symbiotic relationships with nitrogen-fixing bacteria, making it a valuable crop for agricultural purposes. The plant is also used in various traditional medicinal practices and as a source of animal feed.

Due to its adaptability to a range of soil conditions and its ability to improve soil fertility, Lupinus angustifolius has become an important crop in certain regions, particularly in the production of animal feed and as a cover crop to enhance soil health.
